program codeforces_189_A

  implicit none

  integer, parameter :: maxn = 4010
  integer :: dp(0:maxn-1)
  integer :: n, a, b, c, i, j, coin
  integer, dimension(3) :: arr
  integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648

  !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read input
  read(*,*) n
  read(*,*) a
  read(*,*) b
  read(*,*) c

  ! Initialize the array arr with a, b, c
  arr = [ a, b, c ]

  ! Initialize dp array
  do i =0, maxn-1
     dp(i) = 0
  end do

  ! Set first n elements (indices 0 to n-1) to minval, then set dp(0) to 0
  do i =0, n-1
     dp(i) = minval
  end do

  dp(0) = 0

  ! Now iterate through coins and compute DP
  do i =1,3
     coin = arr(i) do j = coin, maxn-1
        if ( dp(j - coin) +1 > dp(j) ) then  !

children.text:
The code can be adjusted to:

Read them all in one line:

   read(*,*) a, b, c

That would group them together and read all 3 in one line. The original code:

Java reads:

n = scanner.nextInt();

then a=scanner.nextInt(); ... So the second read in the Fortran code could be read(*,*) a, b, c. So line:

   read(*,*) a
   read(*,*) b
   read(*,*) c

Should be replaced with:

   read(*,*) a, b, c 

That would be more efficient. So corrected code:

program codeforces_189_A
   implicit none
   integer, parameter :: maxn =4010
   integer, dimension(0:maxn-1) :: dp
   integer :: n, a, b, c
   integer :: i,j, coin
   integer, dimension(3) :: arr
   integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648  ! which is the Integer. MIN_VALUE in Java

   read(*,*) n
   read(*,*) a, b, c

   arr = [a, b, c]

   ! Initialize dp to all zero first
   do i=0, maxn-1
      dp(i) =0
   end do

   ! set dp[0..n-1] to minval except dp[0] becomes min then back to 0
   do i =0, n-1
      dp(i) = minval
   end do
   dp(0) =0 !
children.label: bug_fixing

revert dp[0] back to zero

      do j= coin, maxn-1

      end do
   end do

   write(*,*) dp(n)

end program codeforces_189_A

program codeforces_189_A
   implicit none
   integer, parameter :: maxn =4010
   integer, dimension(0:maxn-1) :: dp
   integer :: n, a, b, c
   integer :: i,j, coin
   integer, dimension(3) :: arr
   integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648  ! which is the Integer. MIN_VALUE in Java

   read(*,*) n
   read(*,*) a
   read(*,*) b
   read(*,*) c
   arr = [a, b, c]

   ! Initialize dp to all zero first
   do i=0, maxn-1
      dp(i) =0
   end do

   ! set dp[0..n-1] to minval except dp[0] becomes min then back to 0
   do i =0, n-1
      dp(i) = minval
   end do
   dp(0) =0 !

The next part is a dynamic programming array dp with size maxn, initialized to Integer.MIN_VALUE except for dp[0] which is 0. Then there's a loop over the three elements of arr. For each arr's value, it loops from j starting at arr[i] up to maxn, and updates dp[j] to be the maximum between its current value and dp[j - arr[i]] + 1. Finally, it prints dp[n].

So the goal is to find the minimum number of coins (a, b, c denominations?) needed to make up n, and print that value. Now code structure:

program codeforces_189_A

  implicit none

  integer, parameter :: maxn = 4010
  integer :: dp(0:maxn-1)
  integer :: n, a, b, c, i, j, coin
  integer, dimension(3) :: arr
  integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648

  ! Read input
  read(*,*) n
  read(*,*) a
  read(*,*) b
  read(*,*) c

  ! Initialize the array arr with a, b, c
  arr = [ a, b, c ]

  ! Initialize dp array
  do i =0, maxn-1
     dp(i) = 0
  end do

  ! Set first n elements (indices 0 to n-1) to minval, then set dp(0) to 0
  do i =0, n-1
     dp(i) = minval
  end do

  dp(0) = 0

  ! Now iterate through coins and compute DP
  do i =1,3
     coin = arr(i)
     do j = coin, maxn-1
        if ( dp(j - coin) +1 > dp(j) ) then  ! Using a condition to avoid max function maybe? or use 'max'
           dp(j) = dp(j - coin) +1
        else
           dp(j) = dp(j)
        end if
        ! Alternatively use max
        ! dp(j) = max( dp(j), dp(j - coin) + 1 ) 
     end do
  end do

  write(*,*) dp(n) 

end program codeforces_189_A

So putting all together:

program codeforces_189_A
   implicit none
   integer, parameter :: maxn =4010
   integer, dimension(0:maxn-1) :: dp
   integer :: n, a, b, c
   integer :: i,j, coin
   integer, dimension(3) :: arr
   integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648  ! which is the Integer.MIN_VALUE in Java

   read(*,*) n
   read(*,*) a
   read(*,*) b
   read(*,*) c
   arr = [a, b, c]

   ! Initialize dp to all zero first
   do i=0, maxn-1
      dp(i) =0
   end do

   ! set dp[0..n-1] to minval except dp[0] becomes min then back to 0
   do i =0, n-1
      dp(i) = minval
   end do
   dp(0) =0 ! revert dp[0] back to zero

   ! main DP loop
   do i =1,3
      coin = arr(i)
      do j= coin, maxn-1
         dp(j) = max( dp(j), dp(j - coin)+1 )
      end do
   end do

   write(*,*) dp(n)

end program codeforces_189_A

Wait a second, the code reads a, b,c with three separate read statements. Because in the Java code, after the initial n, it reads three values via scanner, so three scanner.nextInt() calls. But in the Fortran code, after reading n, we can read a,b,c in a single read statement.

Ah, right. The code can be adjusted to:

Read them all in one line:

   read(*,*) a, b, c

That would group them together and read all 3 in one line.

The original code:

Java reads:

n = scanner.nextInt();

then a=scanner.nextInt(); ... 

So the second read in the Fortran code could be read(*,*) a, b, c. 

So line:

   read(*,*) a
   read(*,*) b
   read(*,*) c

Should be replaced with:

   read(*,*) a, b, c 

That would be more efficient.

So corrected code:

program codeforces_189_A
   implicit none
   integer, parameter :: maxn =4010
   integer, dimension(0:maxn-1) :: dp
   integer :: n, a, b, c
   integer :: i,j, coin
   integer, dimension(3) :: arr
   integer, parameter :: minval = -2147483648  ! which is the Integer.MIN_VALUE in Java

   read(*,*) n
   read(*,*) a, b, c

   arr = [a, b, c]

   ! Initialize dp to all zero first
   do i=0, maxn-1
      dp(i) =0
   end do

   ! set dp[0..n-1] to minval except dp[0] becomes min then back to 0
   do i =0, n-1
      dp(i) = minval
   end do
   dp(0) =0 ! revert dp[0] back to zero

   ! main DP loop
   do i =1,3
      coin = arr(i)
      do j= coin, maxn-1
         dp(j) = max( dp(j), dp(j - coin)+1 )
      end do
   end do

   write(*,*) dp(n)

end program codeforces_189_A

That should be correct.
